title: Does freedom of speech include rude speech? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hell yes - is my BNBR reply. There are limits to every kind of freedom or duty in society. For the simple but very consequential fact that society means LOTS of people together. So freedom of speech is not some universal or natural or holy right. For instance shouting fire in a crowded enclosed space for fun is criminal and will be punished I think everywhere. Rudeness is just impolite behaviour. The use of it has its own inbuilt punishment. Religious respect is also not a requirement. But before you go all out, freedom of speech does not mean freedom from consequences. Depending on local law, people can snub you, answer you back, fire you, express THEIR freedom of speech, etc… Tiny example: if you are a German and you are on video declaring “kind and wise Hitler would have known what to do with refugees and I would help him do it” , your employer would fire you faster than you can say heil. I think most close knitted religious communities do not want to know about your atheism and if you are a dick about it they will stop inviting you. If you want to tell a rugby team loudly and graphically what you think about their gay captain, you might want to wear your running shoes. If you as a shop owner tell that shamelessly lesbian couple you don’t need their business, don’t be surprised your cute little shop suddenly pops up on social and other media. In fact be glad, you probably won’t see any gay customers for years to come, and you’ll have a pretty good idea who is closeted or has a more inclusive view on humanity: the usual customers who suddenly don’t show up anymore.

Of course. Speech that offends is the only kind that needs protection. No one tries to shut down speech that doesn't offend anyone. The main purpose of free speech is so that people can criticize their government. Without the ability to do that, the people aren't in charge of their government. The moment you let government decide what qualifies as free speech, you no longer have free speech.

Rude speech is included. However, other people responding to that rude speech are also protected by the first amendment, and if they want to yell over you until you stop, they are welcome to. One thing that is not protected, however, is an incitement to racial, ethnic or religious hatred or violence, particularly if you have the power to actually carry it out or order others to carry it out.

Yes, it does. Constitutional guarantees of free expression exist in every developed nation, and they make no exception for rude speech. No one in those nations has the right not to be offended. However, the owners of various communication media (e.g., Quora) in any of those nations may limit free speech as a condition of participation, and they’re free to do so in pretty much any way they choose.

Rude speech is protected by the First Amendment. Congress shall pass no law abridging your freedom to speak rudely, but this does not guarantee that you won’t be punched in the nose.
Of course it does. No one needs freedom in order to say things no one objects to. Freedom of speech only matters when the things being said offend people in some way.

Speech includes manners. With or without freedom, one should not be rude. You can say anything you want, about any topic, with good manners and discipline. Without being rude or disrespectful to others.

Keep in mind that “freedom of speech” only means that the government may not limit your speech. It doesn’t mean that people have the right to say whatever they want at work or at private gatherings or restaurants where the boss or owner has every right to “limit” their speech.
